## Selected projects in data science, machine learning and NLP

---

### Custom Object Detection using YOLOv3

This project involves implementing a custom object detection system using the state-of-the-art YOLOv3 algorithm. YOLOv3 (You Only Look Once version 4) is an efficient and accurate deep learning model that can detect objects in real-time, making it well-suited for various applications such as security, autonomous vehicles, and robotics. By training YOLOv3 on a custom dataset of images, this project aims to develop a customized object detection system capable of detecting specific objects in real-world scenarios.

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Tensorflow-white?logo=Tensorflow)](#) 

[View Repository](https://github.com/mattekudacy/yolo-train-assignment)

---

### Spotify Analysis and Reccomendation System Based on Most Liked vs Disliked Songs
This project is all about analyzing and recommending music on Spotify based on what people love and hate. By looking at the most liked and disliked songs on the platform, the project aims to find patterns and insights that can be used to make personalized music recommendations. Using data analysis tools and Spotify's APIs, the system can gather information about tracks, genres, and listening habits to create a custom playlist.

<img src="images/heatmap-spotify.png?raw=true" />
<img src="images/ML-metrics.png?raw=true" />

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Jupyter-white?logo=Jupyter)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Spotify%20API-white?logo=Spotify)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/pandas-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) 

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)


[View Repository](https://github.com/mattekudacy/spotify-recommendation-and-analysis)

---

### Iris Flower Dataset Classification Model using Pytorch
This project is a classification model built using PyTorch, which predicts the species of an iris flower based on its characteristics. The model is trained on the famous Iris Flower Dataset, which contains measurements of the sepal length, sepal width, petal length, and petal width for three different species of iris flowers.

The project was completed as a capstone project in the "AI Programming with Python Nanodegree" course by Udacity. The project involved preprocessing the data, creating and training the model using PyTorch, and evaluating the performance of the model on a test set. The final model achieved high accuracy in predicting the species of iris flowers, demonstrating the effectiveness of deep learning techniques for classification tasks.

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Jupyter-white?logo=Jupyter)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Pytorch-white?logo=Pytorch)](#)  [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/pandas-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)

[View Repository](https://github.com/mattekudacy/udacity_ai)

---

### Developing an NBO Model on Insurance Products using Machine Learning
In this project, I developed an NBO (Next Best Offer) model for insurance products using machine learning techniques. The project involved extensive data preparation, cleaning, analysis, and sharing. Multiple ML techniques such as GBMs (Gradient Boosting Machines) and sampling techniques were explored and implemented on the dataset to achieve the highest F1-Score possible.

The specifics of the project cannot be disclosed in detail due to confidentiality agreements and the need to protect sensitive company information.

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Jupyter-white?logo=Jupyter)](#)
 [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/pandas-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)

### Agent Clustering Model
In this project, the main objective is to identify the top performing agents using unsupervised learning techniques. To achieve this goal, multiple pre-processing techniques were implemented to obtain the ideal cluster, distortion, and silhouette score. After clustering, the metrics of each cluster were visualized, and outlier detection was applied to determine the top agents. 

The specifics of the project cannot be disclosed in detail due to confidentiality agreements and the need to protect sensitive company information.

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Jupyter-white?logo=Jupyter)](#)
 [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/pandas-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)

---

### Colored Pen Tracing Using Computer Vision
Colored pen tracing using computer vision is a project that utilizes computer vision techniques to track and trace the movement of a colored pen. The goal of the project is to develop an algorithm that can detect and track the pen's movements in real-time and reproduce its path on a digital canvas.

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/OpenCV-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)

[View Repository](https://github.com/mattekudacy/color-pen-drawing)

---

### Virtual Keyboard using Hand Gesture Recognition
This project uses computer vision techniques to recognize hand gestures and translate them into keyboard inputs. The system tracks the user's hand movements, identifies the hand gestures using OpenCV, and maps them to corresponding keyboard inputs. The user can interact with the virtual keyboard by moving their hand in front of a camera and using various hand gestures to select and press keys. The project is implemented in Python and uses the cvzone module for hand detection and tracking, and the pynput module for keyboard emulation.. 


[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/NumPy-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#) [![](https://img.shields.io/badge/OpenCV-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)](#)


[View Repository](https://github.com/mattekudacy/ai-virtual-keyboard)

<!-- ### Did lockdowns influence the types of music people were listening to?
COVID-19 has created an ostensible paradox in the music industry. In the four months after the World Health Organisation declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11, 2020, digital music streaming providers such as Spotify and Apple saw their share prices soar by 114% and 49% respectively (Google 2021b). Over the same period, however, worldwide digital music consumption dropped by an average of 12.5% (Sim et al. 2021). One of the reasons which has been suggested for this drop is the decline in certain types of mobility - especially driving, which accounts for 29% of music consumption, and commuting, as 54% of commuters listen to music while commuting (Nielsen 2015, 2017; Sim et al. 2021). What remains unclear, however, is whether and how changes to levels of mobility influenced the types of music to which people were listening. In this project, I investigate these questions using the Spotify API.

<img src="images/spotify.png?raw=true" />
